content: D.C. Council Votes to Recognize Same-Sex Marriage Performed in Other States 13-0 without debate. May 5, 2009 Washington Post reporter Tim Craig relays that the D.C. Council has voted 13-0, without debate, to recognize same-sex marriages performed in other states. Watch D.C. Wire for updates. If Congress does not intervene, council member David A. Catania (I-At Large) has said that he will introduce a separate bill this year to allow same-sex marriages to be performed in the District. The positioning comes amid uncertainty about whether the same-sex marriage question could eventually land before District voters. Source: ABC News

Catania (I-At Large) has said that he will introduce a separate bill this year to allow same-sex marriages to be performed in the District. The positioning comes amid uncertainty about whether the same-sex marriage question could eventually land before District voters. Source: ABC News
title: D.C. Council Votes to Recognize Same-Sex Marriage Performed in Other States 13-0

content: This is a unique situation, Washington DC is not part of a State and Congress makes the final decisions on laws enacted for the District of Columbia (DC). This may force Congress to review the Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) which bars federal recognition of same-sex marriages. The outcome could be a Constitutional showdown on the legality of DOMA.

title: D.C. Council Votes to Recognize Same-Sex Marriage Performed in Other States 13-0

content: Indeed it could. No matter how you look at it this is going to be an interesting and active summer.
reply: Indeed it could. No matter how you look at it this is going to be an interesting and active summer.
title: D.C. Council Votes to Recognize Same-Sex Marriage Performed in Other States 13-0

content: D.C. Marriage: Next Stop, Congress The battle over Washington D.C.’s right to recognize out-of-state gay marriages will now likely move to the U.S. Congress, which has oversight over all bills approved by the District’s city government. The Washington, D.C., city council voted 12-1 Tuesday to pass a bill recognizing same-sex marriages in the District. Assuming Mayor Adrian Fenty makes good on his pledge to sign the measure, Congressional Republicans appear to be gearing up to oppose the District’s right to self-determination. "Some things are worth fighting for, and this is one of them," Rep. Jason Chaffetz of Utah, the ranking Republican on the subcommittee that oversees the District, told The Washington Post. "I recognize the Democrats are in the majority, but I represent the majority of Americans on this issue." Full article at ... >>>http://www.advocate.com/news_detail_ektid82670.asp
